ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Read and discussed poetry; assembled a poetry portfolio by writing throughout the semester at the pace of a poem every week; developed revising and editing skills

I learned how to take the art I admire and put it in conversation with my own practice to better understand themes of femininity, objectification, and intimacy. It was essential to helping me articulate my work as an artist as effectively as I have written about other artists.

This course is an amazing opportunity to work one-on-one with Yale's stellar writing faculty. I got more out of this tutorial than I have out of maybe any other course I've taken at Yale (and that's saying a lot)! Anyone who is serious about writing should do their best to take a tutorial.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This independent study has been one of the most rewarding academic experiences I've had at Yale. 
Perhaps it could have benefited from a more systematic editing / workshop space built into the weekly discussions (though I hesitate to make this note because every non-workshop-focused conversation was so illuminating and dynamic.)
It's all strengths. I kind of can't believe this program exists. More people should take advantage of the opportunity to work individually with their favorite professors.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would! In particular, I thought that Prof. Roffman and Prof. Kuhl worked so well together and the small cohort (just myself and one other student) made the writing experience that much more intimate and generative.
Yes! If they are interested in improving their writing while doing a deep investigation into a subject of their choice.

Yes, if you are willing to be very self-directed. At least in my experience, I was in charge of coming up with what was due each week. I really liked that opportunity, but if you want your professor to direct you, you should probably say so up front.
